Factsheet

Developer:
University of Connecticut
CT, USA
Release Date:
June 1, 2023
Platforms:
Web Browser
Website:
edtech.education.uconn.edu/eos-503
Price:
Free

Description

EOS-503 is a browser-based game for teaching and assessing educator problem solving, built around a combination of contemporary learning theory and instructional technology integration skills. It encourages players to explore a fictitious space station, hone their communication skills with a diverse set of stakeholders, and overcome richly-authentic challenges grounded in the TPACK model and ISTE Standards.

By “richly-authentic challenges,” we mean that educators are provided an opportunity to solve realistic problems the way they would actually solve them in the real world. This is achieved through three primary pillars of design:

  1. Situating various learning theories in a context where their application makes real-world sense;
  2. Demonstrating the consequences of adopting particular instructional technologies through particular pedagogical worldviews (as defined by the TPACK model and ISTE standards); and
  3. Maintaining a 1:1 ratio of game objectives and instructional objectives to reduce barriers to transfer and to make it easier for teachers to directly apply what they have learned.

Through maintenance of the 1:1 ratio between EOS-503's play objectives and our broader instructional objectives, the game is able to teach and assess how particular educators think about the integration of technology and contemporary learning theory into their particular educational classroom environments.

EOS-503 is not a form of direct instruction, nor does it ask the player to memorize or manipulate abstracted symbols and patterns. It is instead a narrative adventure that presents educators with problems of practice alongside multiple theory-based educational worldviews and interactive opportunities that encourage rethinking and evolving one’s personal philosophy of education and cognition. Our goal is to ultimately make this resource available to all educators at no cost such that it may benefit as many teacher education, educational technology, learning science, and other instructional training spaces as possible.

History

EOS-503 first started development in the spring of 2019, when three students at the University of Connecticut were tasked with creating an educational game. Basing their work on multiple earlier attempts to design a game to teach learning theory, these students created the prototype that would become the foundation for EOS-503. A year later one of those students met a group of game design students, pitched them the idea, and together they started refining and developing this prototype into a playable game. This work led to version 1 of EOS-503, launched in June 2022, and we have since worked to further refine EOS-503, as well as add new content to the game! As we continue to add new content to EOS-503 we are ensuring that our goal of aligning gameplay objectives and mechanisms with learning objectives and realistic actions, is maintained.

Features

  • Single player narrative adventure in a semi-open world
  • Customizable character creation that can be changed at any time
  • Unique narrative gameplay where everything you say matters
  • Realistic problem solving grounded in theories of learning
